div.p: THE PHOENIX, AS It hath beene sundry times Acted by the Children of Paules, And presented before his Maiestie.
LONDON Printed by E.A. for A, I, and are to be solde at the signe of the white horse in Paules-Churchyard. 1607.

div.head: THE Phoenix:
div.stage: Enter the old Duke of Ferrara, Nobles, Proditor, Lussurioso, and Infesto, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: MY Lordes,
Know that we far from any naturall pride
Or touch of temporall sway, haue seene our face
In our graue counsels foreheads: where doth stand
Our truest glasse, made by Times wrinckled hand.
We know wee're old, my daies proclayme me so:
Fortie-fiue yeres, I'ue gently ruld this Dukedome,
Pray heauen it be no fault,
For there's as much disease, though not to th' eye,
In too much pittie, as in Tyrannie.

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: Your grace hath spoke it right.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know that life
Has not long course in me, twill not be long
Before I show that Kinges haue mortall bodies
As well as Subjects, therefore to my comfort,
And your succesfull hopes I haue a Sonne
Whome I dare boast of;—

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Whome we all do boast off,
A Prince elder in vertues then in yeares,

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: His iudgement is a Father to his youth,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I, I, would he were from Court,

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: Our largest hopes grow in him,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And tis the greatest pittie Noble Lord,
He is vntraueld,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Tis indeede my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Had he but trauaile to his time and Vertue— oh hee should neere returne agen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It shall be so, what is in hope begun,
Experience quickens, trauaile confirmes the man,
Who's else liues doubtfull, and his daies oft sorye,
"Who's rich in Knowledge, ha's the stocke of glorye.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Most true my royall Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Some one attend our Sonne.

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: See, heere hee comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh you come well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Tis alwaies my desire my worthy Father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your Serious studyes, & those fruitfull howres
That grow vp into iudgement, well become
Your birth, and all our loues: I weepe that you are my sonne,
But Vertuously I weepe, the more my gladnes:
We haue thought good and meete by the consent
Of these our Nobles, to moue you toward Trauaile,
The better to approue you to your selfe
And giue your apter power, foundation:
To see affections actually praesented,
Ee'n by those men that owe them, yeeld more profit,
I more content, then singly to reade of them,
"Since loue or feare, make Writers partiall,
The good and free example which you finde,
In other Countries, match it with your owne,
The ill to shame the ill, which will in time,
Fully instruct you how to set in frame,
A kingdome all in peeces.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Honoured Father,
With care and duetie I haue listned to you,
What you desire, in me it is obedience,
I doe obey in all, knowing for right,
"Experience is a Kingdomes better sight.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh tis the verie lustre of a Prince,
Trauaile! tis sweete and generous,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He that knowes how to obey, knowes how to reigne
And that true knowledge haue we found in you,
Make choice of your Attendants.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Theyr soone chose, only this man my Lord, a louing seruant of mine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What none but he?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I doe intreate no more,
For that's the benefit a priuate Gentleman
Enioyes beyond our state, when he notes all,
Himselfe vnnoted,
For should I beare the fashion of a prince,
I should then win more flatterie, then profit,
And I should giue e'm time & warning then
To hide their Actions from me, if I appeare a Sunne,
Theile run into the shade with their ill deedes,
And so preuent me.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A little too wise, a little too wise to liue long.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You haue answered vs with wisdome, let it be.
Things priuate are best known through priuacy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stay you my elected seruant.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My kinde Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Duke my Father has a heauy burthen,
Of yeares vpon him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord it seemes so, for they make him stoope.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Without dissemblance hee is deepe in age,
He bowes vnto his graue, I wonder much
Which of his wilde Nobilitie it should bee
(For none of his sad counsell has a voyce in't)
Should so farre trauaile into his consent,
To set me ouer into other Kingdomes.
Vpon the stroke and minute of his death?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord, tis easier to suspect them all,
Then truly to name one.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Since it is thus,
By absence, ile obey the Duke my father,
And yet not wrong my selfe.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Therein my Lord,
You might be happie twice.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So it shall bee,
Ile stay at home, and trauaile;

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Would your Grace
Could make that good.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I can, & indeed a Prince need no trauaile farther then his owne Kingdome, if hee applie himselfe faythfullye, worthie the glorie of himselfe and expectation of others: and it would appeare farre nobler industrie in him, to reforme those fashions that are alreadye in his Countrey, then to bring newe ones in, which haue neither true forme nor fashion; to make his Court an Owle, Cittie an Ape, and the Countrey a Wolfe, preying vpon the ridiculous pride of eyther, and therefore I holde it a safer sterne vpon this luckie aduantage, since my father is nere his setting, and I vpon the Easterne hil to take my rise, to look into the heart & bowels of this Dukedome, and in disguise, marke all abuses readie for Reformation or Punishment.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Giue me but leaue vnfainedly to admire you,
Your wisdome is so spacious and so honest,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
So much haue the complaints and suits of men, seauen, nay seauenteene yeares neglected, stil interposd by coine and great enemies, preuaild with my pittie, that
I cannot otherwise thinke but there are infectious dealings in most offices, and foule misteries throughout al Professions: and therefore I nothing doubt but to find trauaile ynough within my selfe, and Experience I fear too much: nor will I be curious to fit my bodie to the humblest forme and bearing, so the labor may be fruitfull: for how can abuses that keepe lowe, come to the right view of a Prince, vnlesse his lookes lie leuell with them, which else will be longest hid from him, hee shall be the last man sees 'em.
sp.l: For oft betwene Kings Eyes, and subiects Crimes
Stands there a barre of brybes, the vnder office
Flatters him next aboue it: he the next,
And so of most, or manye, Euerie Abuse will chuse a brother,
Tis through the world, this Hand will rub the other.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You haue set downe the worlde briefly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But how am I assur'd of faith in thee?
Yet I durst trust thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Let my soule be lost,
sp.p: When it shall loose your secrets: nor will I onely bee a preseruer of them, but if you so please an assister.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: It suffices:
That King stands sur'st who by his vertue rises
More then by birth or blood, that Prince is rare,
Who striues in youth to saue his age from care,
Let's be preparde away.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ile follow your Grace,
Thou wonder of all Princes, President, and Glorie,
True Phoenix, made of an vnusuall straine,
"Who labours to reforme is fit to raigne.
How can that King be safe that studies not
The profite of his people? See where comes
The best part of my heart, my loue.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to find you, I heard newly
Of suddaine Trauaile which his grace intends
And onely but your selfe to accompany him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You heard in that, little beside the truth,
Yet not so suddaine as to want those manners,
To leaue you vnregarded.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I did not thinke, so vnfashionably of you:
How long is your returne?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Tis not yet come to me, scarce to my Lord,
Vnlesse the Duke referre it to his pleasure,
But long I thinke it is not, the Dukes age,
(If not his apt experience) will forbid it.

sp.speaker: Neec.
sp.l: His grace commaunds, I must not think amisse, farwell

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay stay, and take this comfort,
You shall heare often from vs, ile direct
Where you shall surely knowe, and I desire you
Write me the Truth, how my new father in lawe, the
Captaine beares himselfe toward my Mother,
For that marriage, knew nothing of my minde,
It neuer flourisht in any part of my affection.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Me thinkes sha's much disgrac'd herselfe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nothing so: if he be good & wil abide the touch, a Captaine may marrie a Lady, if hee can saile into her good will.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Indeede thats all,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Tis al in al, commend me to thy brest, farwel.
So by my Lords firme pollicy we may see,
To present view, what absent formes would be.

div.stage: Enter the Captaine with Souldiering fellowes.

sp.l: There's Noble purchase Captaine.
Nay admirable purchase.
Ynough to make vs proud for euer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hah?
Neuer was opportunitie so Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why you make me madde.
Three Ships not a poope lesse.

sp.p: And euerieone so wealthily burdned vpon my manhood.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pox on't, and now am I tyed ee'n as the Deuil would ha't.
Captaine, of all men liuing I wold ha' sworne thou wouldst nere haue married.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: S'foot, so would I my selfe man, giue mee my Due, you know I ha sworne all heauen ouer and ouer:

sp.l: That you haue y faith.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why goe too then.

sp.p: Of a man that has tasted salt water to commit such a fresh Tricke.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why tis abhominable I grant you now I see't:
Had there beene fewer Women—
And among those Women fewer Drabs—
And among those Drabs fewer pleasing—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then t'ad beene something:

sp.p: But when there are more women, more common pretty sweete hearts, then euer any age could boast off.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And I to play the Artificer and marrie: to haue my wife daunce at home, and my Ship at Sea, and both take in salt water together: oh Leiftenant thou'rt happie, thou keepst a Wench.
I hope I am happyer then so Captaine, for a my Troth shee keepes me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How? is there anye such fortunate man breathing? and I so miserable to liue honest? I enuie thee Lieutenant, I enuie thee, that thou art such a happye Knaue, heres my hand among you, share it equally, Ile to sea with you.

sp.l: There spoke a Noble Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Lets heare from you, there will be newes shortly.
Doubt it not Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
What lustfull passion came aboord of mee, that
I should marrye, was I drunke? yet that cannot altogether holde, for it was foure a clocke 'ith morning, had it beene fiue, I would ha sworne it: that a man is in danger euerie minute to be cast away, without hee haue an extraordinarie Pilot that can performe more then a man can doe: and to say truth too, when 'ime abroad what can I doe at home? no man liuing can reach so farre: & what a horrible thing t'would bee to haue hornes brought me at Sea, to looke as if the Deuill were 'ith ship: and all the greate Tempestes would bee thought of my Raysing, to bee the generall cursse of all Merchants: and yet they likely are as deepe in as my selfe, and thats a comfort: O that a Captaine should liue to be marryed! nay, I that haue beene such a Gallant salt-theefe, should yet liue to be marryed: What a fortunate Elder Brother is he, whose father being a Ramish Plough-man, himselfe a perfumde Gentleman, spending the labouring reeke from his Fathers: Nosthrils in Tobacco: the sweate of his Fathers bodye in monthlye Phisick for his pretty quesie Harlot: he sowes a pace 'ith Countrie: the Taylor oretakes him i'th Cittie, so that often times before the Corne comes to Earning, tis vp to the eares in high Collars, and so at euerie haruest the Reapers take paines for the Mercers, ha! why this is stirring happinesse indeede, would my father had held a plow so, and fed vpon squeaz'd Curds and Onions, that I might haue bath'd insensualitie: but hee was too ruttish himselfe to let me thriue vnder him, cansumde me before hee got me, & that makes me so wretched, now to be shackled with a wife, & not greatly rich neither.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Captaine, my Husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: S'life call me husband agen, & ile play the Captaine and beate you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What ha's disturb'd you sir, that you now looke so like an Enemie vpon me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Goe make a Widdower, hang thy selfe,
How comes it that you are so opposite
To loue and kindenes? I deserue more Respect,
But that you please to be forgetfull of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For loue to you, did I neglect my state,
Chide better fortunes from me,
Gaue the world talke, laide all my friendes at waste.

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.l: The more foole you, could you like none but me?
Could none but I supplye you?
I am sure you were sued to, by far worthyer men,
Deeper in wealth and Gentrie.
What couldst thou see in me, to make thee doate so on me,
sp.p: If I knowe, I am a Villaine: what a torments this? why didst thou marry me? you thinke as most of your insatiate Widdowes, that Captaines can doe wonders, when 'lasse the name do's often proue the better man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That which you vrge, should rather giue me cause to repent then your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then to that end I doo't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What a miserable state am I led into?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: How now sir?

sp.speaker: Seruus:
sp.l: Count Proditer is now alighted.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What, my Lord: I must make much of him, heele one day write me Cuckold: tis good to make much of such a man, ee'n to my face, hee plyes it hard I thanke him:—
what, my worthy Lord!

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Ile come to you in order Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: Oh thats in order: a kisse is the Gammoth to pricksong.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Let me salute you Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My deere esteemed Count, I haue a life for you:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Heare you the newes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What may it be my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dukes Sonne is vpon his trauaile to seuerall Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: May it bee possible my Lord, and yet so little rumord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Tak't of my Truth, nay, twa's well manag'd, thinges are as they are handled: but all my care is still, pray heauen hee returne safe, without danger Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why, is there any doubt to bee had of that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I by my faith Captaine.
Princes haue priuate enemies, and great:
Put case a man should grudge him, for his Vertues:
Or enuie him, for his wisdome: why you know
This makes him lye bare brested to his foe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: That's ful of certaintie my Lord, but who be his Attendants?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Thence Captaine comes the feare, but singlie attended neither (my best gladnes) only by your Sonne in Law Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is it to be beleeu'd? I promise you my Lord then I beginne to feare him my selfe, that fellow will vndoe him: I durst vndertake to corrupt him with twelue pence ouer and aboue, and thats a small matter: ha's a whorish Conscience, hee's an inseperable Knaue, and I could neere speake well of that fellow.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: All wee of the younger house, I can tell you do doubt him much,— the Ladyes remoou'd, shall we haue your sweete soscietie Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Though it bee in mine owne house, I desire I may follow your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I loue to auoide strife,
Not many monthes Phoenix shall keepe his life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: So, his way is in, he knowes it,
We must not be vncurteous to a Lord,
sp.p: Warne him our house t'were vilde: his presence is an honour, if he lie with our wiues, tis for our credite, wee shall be the better trusted, tis a signe wee shall liue ith world: O Tempests and Whirlewinds (who but that man whom the forefinger cannot daunt, that makes his shame his liuing:) Who but that man I say, could endure to be throughly married? Nothing but a diuorce can relieue me: any way to be rid of her would rid my torment: if all meanes faile Ile kil, or poyson her, and purge my fault at sea: but first Ile make gentle Trie of a Diuorce: But how shal I accuse her subtle honestie? Ile attach this Lords comming to her, take hold of that: ask counsell: and now I remember, I haue acquaintance with an olde craftie Client, who by the puzzle of suites & shifting of Courts, has more tricks & starting holes, then the dizzie pates of fifteene Atturneys: one that has beene muzled in Law like a Beare, and lead by the Ring of his spectacles from office to office: him Ile seeke out with haste, all paths Ile tread,
sp.l: All deathes Ile die ere I die married.

div.stage: Enter Proditor with the Captaines wife.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Puh, you doe resist me hardly.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I beseech your Lordship cease in this,
sp.p: Tis neuer to be granted: if you come as a friend vnto my honour and my husband, you shall be euer welcome, if not, I must intreate it—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why assure your selfe, Madame, tis not the fashion.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Tis more my griefe my Lord, such as my selfe are iudg'd the worse for such.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Faith y'are too nice, youle see me kindly forth:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And honourably welcome.

div.stage: Enter a Groome before Phoenix, and Fidelio, alighting into an Inne.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Gentlemen, y'are moste neately welcome.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Y'are very cleanelye Sir, prethee haue a care to our Geldings.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Your Geldings shall be well considered.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Considered?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sirha, what Guesse do's this Inne holde now?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Some fiue and twentie Gentlemen besides their beastes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Their Beastes?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Their wenches I meane sir, for your worship knowes those that are vdder men are beastes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How do's your Mother sit?

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: Verie well in health I thanke you heartily sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And so is my Mare y faith.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Ile doe her commendations indeede sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Well kept vp Shuttle-cocke:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what olde fellow was he that newly alighted before vs?

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.p: Who he? as arrant a craftie fellow as ere made water on horsebacke: some say hee's as good as a Lawyer, (marrie 'ime sure hee's as bad as a Knaue) if you haue any suites in lawe, hee's the fittest man for your companie: ha's beene so toward and lug'd himselfe, that hee is able to affoord you more knauish counsell for tenne groates, then another for ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: A fine fellowe: but doe you know him to be a Knaue, and will lodge him.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p:
Your worship begins to talke idlely, your bed shall be made presently; if we should not lodge knaues, I wonder how we should bee able to liue honestlye, are there honest men enough thinke you in a Terme time to fill all the Innes in the towne, and as far as I can see, a knaues Gelding eats no more hay then an honest mans: nay theeues Gelding eates lesse, ile stand too't, his Maister
allowes him a better Ordnarie: yet I haue my eightpence day & night, twere more for our profit I wus, you were all theeues, if you were so contented: I shall bee cald for: giue your worships good morrow.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A royall knaue y faith: wee haue hapned into a Godly Inne.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Assure you my L. they belong al to one church.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This shold be some olde busie turbulent fellowe: villanous Law-worme, that eates holes into poore mens causes.

sp.l: May it please your worship to giue me leaue?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I giue you leaue sir, you haue your Veniam, now fill me a browne Toste sirha.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Will you haue no drink too't sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Is that a question in lawe?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Yes, in the lowest Court: 'ith Sellor sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Let me haa't remou'd presently sir.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: It shall bee done sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now as you were saying Sir, ile come to you immediately too.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh verie wel sir:

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I'me a little busie sir,
But as how sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I pray sir?
Ha's brought me into the Court, marry my aduersarie ha's not declarde yet.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non declarauit Aduersarius saist thou: what a Villain's that, I haue a tricke to doe thee good: I will get thee out a Proxe, & make him declare with a Poxe to him.

sp.l: That wil make him declare to his fore griefe, I thank your good worship: but put case he doe declare?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Si declarasset, If he should declare there,
I would be loath to stand out to the iudgement of that Court

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non ad iudicium, doe you feare corruption? then ile releeue you agaen: you shall get a Suersedias, Non molest andam; and remooue it higher her.

sp.l: Verie good.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Now if it should euer come to a Testificandum, what be his witnesses?

sp.l: I little feare his witnesses.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Non metuis testes? more valiant man then Orestes

sp.p: Please you sir to dissolue this into Wine, Ale, or Beere, I come a hundred mile to you I protest, and leaue all other counsell behind me.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Nay you shal alwayes finde me a sound Card, I stoode not ath Pillorie for nothing in eightie eight, all the world knowes that: now let me dispatch you sir; I come to you Presenter.

sp.l: Faith the partie hath remou'd both bodie and cause with a habeas corpus.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Has he that knauerie? But has hee put in baile aboue canst tell?

sp.l: That I can assure your worship, he has not.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why then thy best course shall be, to lay out more money, take out a Procedendo, and bring downe the cause and him with a Vengeance.

sp.l: Then he will come indeed

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: As for the other partie, let the Audita querela alone, take me out a special Supplicauit, which will cost you inough, and then you pepper him. For the first partie after the Procedendo youle get costs, the cause being sound, youle haue a Iudgement, Nunc pro Tunc, youl get a Venire facies to warne your Iurie, a Decem tales to fill vp the number, and a Capias vt Legatum for your execution.

sp.l: I thanke you my learned counsell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: What a busie Caterpiller's this? let's accost him in that maner.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Content my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O my olde admirable fellow, how haue I all this while thirsted to salute thee? I knew thee in Octauo of the Duke.—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: In Octauo of the Duke: I remember the yere well.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: byth masse a lustie proper man.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Oh was I?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But still in lawe

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Still in Law. I had not breath'd else now, tis verie marrow, verie manna to me to be in law: ide been dead ere this else: I haue found such sweete pleasure in the vexation of others, that I could wish my yeares ouer and ouer agen, to see that fellow a Begger, that bawling Knaue a Gentleman: a matter brought 'een to a iudgement to day, as far as ere t'was to begin again to morowe: O Raptures I heere a writ of Demur, there a Procedendo, heere a Sui surrara, there a Capiendo, Tricks, Delayes, Money-lawes:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Is it possible olde Lad?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I haue beene a Tearme-trotter my selfe anye time this fiue and fortie yeares, a goodly time & a gratious: in which space I ha beene at least sixteen times beggard, and got vp agen: and in the mire agen, that I haue stunke agen, and yet got vp agen.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And so cleane and handsome how?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: You see it apparantly, I cannot hide it from you: nay more, in foelice hora bee it spoken, you see i'me olde, yet haue I at this present, nine and twentie sutes in Lawe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Deliuer vs man!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: And all not worth forthy shillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: May it be beleeu'd?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: The pleasure of a man is all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: An olde fellow and such a stinger.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
A stake puld out of my hedge, theres one: I was well beaten I remember, that's two: I tooke one a bed with my wife agen her will, that's three: I was cal'd cuckold for my labour, that's foure: I tooke another a bed agen, that's fiue than one cald me wittal that's sixe: he kild my Dog for Barking, seauen: my Maide Seruant was knockt at that time, eight: my wife miscarryed
with a push, Nine, & sic de coeteris, I haue so vext and beggerd the whole parish, with processe, Suppoeneas, and such like molestations, they are not able to spare so much readie mony from a Tearme, as woulde set vp a new Weather-cocke: the Church-wardens are faine to goe to law with the Poores mony.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: And I so fetch vp al the men euery Tearm time that tis impossible to be at ciuill cuckoldry, within our selues, vnlesse the whole country rise vpon our wiues.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A my faith a prettie pollicie.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Nay an excellent stratagem: but of all I most wonder at the continuall substance of thy wit, that hauing had so many suits in law from time to time, thou hast still mony to relieue 'em.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ha's the best fortune for that, I neuer knew him without.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why doe you so much wonder at that? why this is my course: my Mare and I come vp some fiue dayes before a Tearme.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A good Decorum.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Here I Lodge as you see amongst Innes, and places of most receit—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Verie wittily.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: By which aduantage I diue into Country mens causes, furnish 'em with knauish counsell, little to their profite, buzzing into their Eares, this course, that writ, this office, that Ultimum refugium, as you know I haue words enow for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Enow a conscience y faith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Enow a law, no matter for conscience. For which busie and laborious sweating curtesie, they cannot chuse but feede me with mony, by which I maintaine mine owne suits: ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Why let me hug thee, Caper in mine armes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p:
Another speciall tricke I haue, no body must
know it, which is, to prefer most of those men to one Atturney whom I affect best, to answere which kindnesse of mine, he will sweat the better in my cause, and doe them the lesse good, tak't of my worde, I helpt my Atturney to more Clients the last Tearme then he will dispatch all his life time: I did it.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What a noble memorable deed was there?

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Now sir.

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.p: There's a kind of captaine, verie robustiously enquires for you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: For me? a man of warre: a man of law is fit for a man of warre: we haue no leysure to say prayers: wee both kill a Sunday mornings: Ile not be long from your sweete companie.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: O no I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What captaine might this be?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou Angell sent amongst vs, sober Law.
Made with meeke Eyes, perswading Action,
No lowd immodest Tongue, voic'd like a virgin,
And as chaste from sale,
Saue onely to be heard, but not to raile.
How has abuse deform'd thee to all Eyes?
That where thy vertues sat, thy vices rise,
Yet why so rashly for one villaines fault,
Doe I arraigne whole man? Admired Law,
Thy vpper parts must needes be sacred, pure,
And incorruptible, th'are graue and wise,
T'is but the drosse beneath 'em, and the clowdes
That get betweene thy glorie and their praise,
That make the visible and foule Eclipse,
For those that are neere to thee, are vpright,
As noble in their conscience, as their birth,
Know that damnation is in euery bribe,
And rarely put it from 'em: rate the Presenters,
And scourge 'em with fiue yeares imprisonment,
For off ring but to tempt 'em.
Thus is true iustice exercisde and vsde,
"Woe to the giuer when the Bribe's refusde.
Tis not their wil, to haue law worse then warre,
Where still the poor'st die first,
To send a man without a sheete to his graue,
Or burie him in his Papers.
Tis not their minde it should be, nor to haue
A sute hang longer then a man in chaines
Let him be nere so fastned, they least know
That are aboue, the tedious steps below.
I thanke my time, I doe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I long to know what captaine this should be:

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: See where the Bane or euery cause Returnes.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: S'foote tis the captaine my father in law, my L.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Take heede.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: The Diuorse shall rest then, and the fiue hundred crownes shall stand in full force and vertue.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Then doe you wisely Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A way sayle I, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: A lustie cracke or winde goe with thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: But ah!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Hah:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Remember a Scriuener

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ile haue him for thee. Why thus am I sought after by all professions; heer's a weather beaten Captaine, who not long since newe married to a Ladie widow, would now faine haue sued a Diuorce betweene her and him, but that her honestie is his onely hinderance: to be rid of which, he do's determine to turne her into white mony, and there's a Lord his Chapman has bid fiue hundred Crownes for her alreadie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Or for his part, or whole in her.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Why, do she leaue to sell his wife?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: His wife? I byth masse, he would sell his soule if he knew what Merchant would lay out money vppon't, and some of 'em haue need of one they sweare so fast.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Why, I neuèr heard of the like.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non audiuisti, didst nere heere of that tricke? why Pistor a Baker sold his wife tother day to a cheesemonger, that made Cake and Cheese: another to a Coferer: a third to a common player: why you see tis common: nere feare the Captaine, be ha's not so much witte to bee a praesident himselfe: I promisd to furnish him with an odde Scriuener of mine owne, to draw the bargaine, and sale of his Lady, your horses stand heere Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I shall bee busilye plung'd till towards bed time, aboue the chin in profundis.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What monstrous daies are these?
Not onely to be vicious, most men study,
But in it to be vgly, striue to exceed,
Each other in the moste deformed deede.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Was this her priuate choice? did shee neglect
The presence and opinion of her friends, for this?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I wonder who that one should be,
Should so disgrace that Reuerend Name of Lord,
So loathsomly to buy Adulterie?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: We may make meanes to knowe.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Take courage man, weele beget some defence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I am bound by nature.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: I by Conscience— To sell his Lady: indeed she was a Beast to marrie him, and so he makes of her, come, ile thorowe now 'ime entred.

div.stage: Enter Iewellers wife with a Boy.

sp.speaker: Iew
sp.p: Is my sweete Knight comming, are you certaine hee's comming?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Certaine for sooth, I am sure I saw him out of
the Barbers shop, ere I would come away.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: A Barbers shop, O hee's a trim Knight, would hee venture his body into a Barbers shop, when hee knowes tis as dangerous as a peece of Ireland: O yonder, yonder, hee comes, get you backe agen, and looke you say as I aduiz'de you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You know me mistris?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My maske, my maske.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: My sweete Reuenewe!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: My pleasure welcome: I haue got single, none but you shall accompany mee to the Iustice of peace my Fathers.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Why, is thy Father Iustice of Peace, and I not knowe it?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: My father! yfaith sir I, simply tho I stand heere a Cittizens wife: I am a Iustice of Peaces Daughter.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: I loue thee the better for thy birth.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Hee's at thy seruice my sweete Reuenewe, for thy money paide for e'm.

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: Why then let him run a little before I beseech thee, for a my troth he will discouer vs else.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Hee shall obey thee, before sirrha, trudge: but doe you meane to lye at your Fathers all night?

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Why should I desire your company else?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: S'foot where shall I lye then.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: What an idle question's that? why doe you hinke I cannot make roome for you in my Fathers house, as well as in my husbands, th'are both good for nothing else?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A man so resolute in valour as a Woman in desire, were an absolute Leader.

div.stage: Enter two suters with the Iustice Falso.

sp.p: May it plese your good worship maister Iustice.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Please me and please are your selfe,
Thats my word.

sp.p: The partie your worship sent for, will by no means be brought to appeare.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Hee will not, then what would you aduize me to doe therein?
Onely to graunt your worships warrant, which is of sufficient force to compell him.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: No by my faith: you shall not haue me in that Trap: am I sworne Iustice of Peace, and shall I giue my warrant to fetch a man against his will? why there the peace is Broken, wee must doe all quietly, if hee come hee's welcome, and as far as I can see yet, hees a foole to bee absent, I by this golde is hee (which hee gaue me this morning)
Why, but may it please your good worshippe.—

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I say agen please me and please your selfe, thats my word still.
Sir, the world esteemes it a Common fauour, vpon the Contempt of the partie, the justice to graunt his warrant.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I, tis so common, tis the worse agen, twere the better for me twere otherwise.
I protest sir, and this Gentleman can say as much, it lyes vpon my halfe vndooing.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I cannot see yet, that it should be so— I see not a crosse yet.
I beseech your worship showe me your immediate fauour, and accept this small trifle but as a remembrance to my succeeding Thankfulnes.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Angels? ile not meddle with them, you giue e'm to my wife not to me.
I, I sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
But I pray tell mee nowe, did the partie Vina Voce, with his owne mouth deliuer that contempt, that
that he would not appeare, or did you but iestint?

sp.l: Iest? no a my troth sir, such was his insolent answer

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: And do you thinke it stood with my credite to put vp such an abuse? will he not appeare sayes he? Ile make him appeare with a Vengeance Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: Do's your worship call?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Draw me a strong limbd warrant for the Gentleman speedily, he will be bountifull to thee: goe and thanke him within.
I shall know your worship hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I, I prethee doe. Two Angels one partie, foure another: and I thinke it a great sparke of wisdome and policie (if a man come to me for Iustice) first to knowe his greefes by his fees, which bee light and which bee heauie: he may counterfet els, & make me do Iustice for nothing: I like not that, for when I meane to be iust, let me be paide wel for't: the deed so rare, purges the bribe: how now, what's the newes thou art come so hastily? how fares my Knightly Brother?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Troth he nere farde worse in his life sir: he nere had lesse stomack to his meate since I knew him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Indeede hee's dead sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Newly deceasd I can assure your Worship: the Tabacco-pipe new dropt out of his mouth before I tooke horse, a shrewd signe: I knew then there was no way but one with him, the poore pipe was the last man he took leaue off in this world, who sel in three peeces before him, & seem'd to mourne inwardly, for it lookt as blacke 'th mouth as my maister.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would hee die so like a Polititian, & not once write his minde to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
No Ile say that for him sir: he dyed in the perfect state of memorie, made your worship his ful and whole executor: bequeathing his Daughter, and with her all
his wealth, onely to your disposition.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Did he make such a godly end saist thou? did he die so comfortably, and bequeath all to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Your neece is at hand sir, the will, & the witnesses.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: What a precious ioy and comfort's this, that a Iustices brother can die so wel, nay in such a good and happie memorie, to make me full executor. Wel he was too honest to liue, and that made him die so soone: now I beshrew my heart, I am glad hee's in heauen, has left all his cares and troubles with me, and that great vexation of telling of Money, yet I hope hee had so much grace before he died to turn his white mony into gold, a great ease to his Executor.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: See here comes your Neece my yong mistris sir,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Ah my sweete Neece, let me kisse thee, & drop a teare betweene thy lips: one teare from an old man is a great matter, the cockes of age are drie, thou hast lost a vertuous father, to gaine a notable vncle.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: My hopes now rest in you next vnder heauen

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Let 'em rest, let 'em rest.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Y'are most welcome ere ye begin sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: We are both led by oath and dreadfull promise,
Made to the dying man at his last sence,
First to deliuer these into your hands,
The suerties and reuealers of his state.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: With this his onely daughter and your Neece,
Whose fortunes are at your disposing set,
Vncle and father are in you both met.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Good yfaith, a well spoken Gentleman, y'are not an Esquire sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
Not sir? more's the pitie: by my faith better men then you are, but a great many worse: you see I haue beene a Scholler in my time, tho I'me a Iustice nowe: Neece y'are most happily welcom, the charge of you is
wholy and soly mine owne: and since you are so fortunately come Neece, Ile rest a perpetuall widower.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I take the meaning chaster then the words:
Yet I hope well of both, since it is thus,
His phraise off ends least that's knowne humourous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I make my brother (saies he) full and whole Executor, honestly done of him yfaith, seldome can a man get such a brother: and here again saies he, very vertuously, I bequeath all to him and his disposing: an excellent fellow a my troth, would you might all die no worse, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: But as much better as might be.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Blesse your vprightnesse maister Iustice,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: You'r most soberly welcome sir: daughter y'aue that ye kneele for, rise, salute your weeping coozen.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Weeping coozen?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I coozen.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Eye to weeping is verie proper, and so is the partie that spake it beleeue me, a prettie, fine, slender, streight, delicate knit bodie.
sp.l: Oh how it moues a pleasure through our senses!
How small are womens wastes to their expences?
I cannot see her face, that's vnder water yet.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Newes as cold to the heart as an old mans kindnesse: my vncle dead?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I haue lost the deerest Father.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: If she marry by your consent, choyce and liking make her dowrie fiue thousand crowns: hum, fiue thousand crownes? therefore by my consent shee shall nere marry, I will neither chuse for her, like of it, nor consent too't.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now by the pleasure of my blood a pretty coozen: I would not care, if I were as nere kin to her, as I haue beene to her kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Daughter, what Gentleman might this be?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No Gentleman sir, hee's a Knight.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Is he but a knight? troth, I would a sworne had beene a Gentleman, to see, to see, to see.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Hee's my husbands owne brother, I can tel you (sir:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thy husbands brother: speak certainly prethee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I can assure you father, my husband and hee has laine both in one bellie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile swear then he is his brother indeed, & by the surer side: I craue heartie pardon sweete kinsman that thou hast stood so long vnsaluted in the way of kinred.
sp.l: Welcome to my boord: I haue a bed for thee,
My daughters husbands brother shall commaund,
sp.p: Keyes of my Chests and Chambers.— I haue stable for thy horse, chamber for thy selfe, and a loft abou for thy lowzie lackie, all fit, away with handkirchers, drie vp eies, at funeral we must cry: now let's be wise.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I told you his affection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It fals sweetly.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: But here I bar you from all plots to night,
The time is yet too heauie to be light.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Why, I'me còntent, ile sleepe as chast as you,
And wager night by night who keepes most true.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Well we shall see your temper.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Feare not me Fidelio: become you that inuisible Rope-maker the Scriuener, that binds a man as he walks yet all his ioynts at libertie, aswell as ile fit that common folly of Gentry, the easie-affecting venturer, and no doubt our purpose will arriue most happily.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Chast dutie my Lord works powerfully in mee, and rather then the poore Ladie my mother should fall vpon the common side of rumour to begger her name, I would not only vndergoe all habits, offices, disguiz'd professions, tho ee'n opposite to the temper my blood holds: but in the stainlesse quarrell of her reputation, alter my shape for euer.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p:
I loue thee wealthier, thou hast a noble touch, & by this means which is the only safe means to preserve
thy mother from such an vgly land and sea monster as a counterfeit Captain is, he resigning and basely selling all his estate, title, right, and interest in his Ladie, as the forme of the writing shall testifie.
sp.l: What otherwise can follow but to haue,
A Ladie safe deliuered of a knaue?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am in debt my life, to the free goodnes of your inuentions.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Oh they must euer striue to be so good,
"Who sels his vow is stampt the slaue of blood.

div.stage: Enter Captaine his Ladie following him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Ladi.
sp.l: Captaine, my husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hence, we're at a price for thee, at a price, wants but the telling, and the sealing, then—

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Haue you no sence, neither of my good name or your owne credit?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Credit? pox of credit, that makes me owe so much: it had bine better for me by a thousand Royals I had lost my credite, seauen yeare ago, t'as vndone me, that's it that makes me flie: what neede I to sea else, in the Spring time, when Woods haue leaues, to looke vpon balde Oake.
sp.l: Happier that man say I, whom no man trusts,
It makes him valiant, dares outface the prisons,
Vpon whose carkasse no Gownde Rauen iets,
Oh he that has no credite owes no debts.
Tis time I were rid on't.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Oh why do you so wilfully cherrish your own poyson? and breath against the best of life, chast credit.
sp.l: Well may I call it chast, for like a Maide
Once falsly broke it euer liues decaide.
O Captaine, husband, you name that Dishonest,
By whose good power all that are honest liue,
What madnesse is it to speake ill of that,
Which makes all men speake well, take away credite
By which men amongst men, are well reputed,
That man may liue, but still liues executed.
Oh then shewe pittie to that noble Title
Which else you doe Vsurpe: you'r no true Captaine,
To let your enemies leade you, foule disdaine,
And euerlasting Scandall, Oh beleeue it!
The money you receive for my good name
Will not be halfe enough to pay your shame.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, ile sell thee then to the Smocke: see heere comes my honourable Chapman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh my poyson!
Him, whome mine honour and mine eye abhors.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Lady, what so vniouially departed?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fine shee pollicie? she makes my backe her Bolster, but before my face, she not indures him, Tricks.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Captaine, how haps it she remou'd so strangely?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh for Modesties cause awhile my Lord: shee must restraine her selfe, shee's not yours yet:
sp.l: Beside, it weare not wisdome to appeare,
sp.p: Easie before my sight, fah, wherefore serues modestie but to pleasure a Lady now and then, and help her from susspect, that's the best vse tis put too.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Well obseru'd of a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: No doubt youle be soone friendes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I thinke no lesse.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And make what hast I can to my ship, I durst wager you'l be vnder saile before me.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A pleasant voyage Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I, a verie pleasant voyage as can be: I see the houre is Ripe, heere comes the Prisons Bawde the bond-maker, one that bindes heires before they are begot.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And here are the Crownes Captaine, goe? attend,
Let our bay Courser waite.

div.stage: Enter Phoenix and Fidelio both disguized.

sp.speaker: Lackey.
sp.l: It shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Farmers sonne, ist true?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Has crownes to scatter?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I giue you your salute sir.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I take it not vnthankfully sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I heare a good report of you sir— y'aue money.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I haue so, true.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: An excellent vertue.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I, to keep from you— heare you me Captaine?
sp.p: I haue a certaine generous itch sir, to loose a fewe Angels in the way of profit: tis but a game at Tennis,
sp.l: Where if the ship keepe aboue line, tis three to one:
If not, there's but three hundred Angels gone.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is your venture three hundred? y'are verie pretiously welcome: heere's a voyage towarde will make vs all.—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Beggerly fooles, and swarming knaues.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Captaine, whats he?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Feare him not my Lord, hee's a Gull, hee ventures with me, some filthy Farmers sonne, the father's a Iew, and the sonne a Gentleman: pha.—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Yet he should be a Iew too, for he is new come from giuing ouer swine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why, that in our Countrey makes him a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Goe to, tell your money Captaine.

sp.speaker: Capi
sp.l: Read aloft Scriuener. 1.2.—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To all good and honest Christian people, to whom this present writing shal come: know you for a certain, that I Captaine, for and in the consideration of the sum of fiue hundred crownes, haue clearly bargained, solde, giuen, graunted, assigned and set ouer, and by these presents doe cleerly bargaine, sell, giue, graunt, assigne and set ouer, al the right, estate, title, interest, demaund, possession, and tearme of yeares to come, which I the saide Captaine haue, or ought to haue.—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: If I were as good as I should be,—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
In and to Madona Castiza, my most vertuous,
modest, louing, and obedient wife.—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By my troth my Lord and so she is.— 3.4.5.6.7.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The more Slaue he that sayes it, and not sees it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Togither, with all and singular those admirable qualities with which her noble brest is furnisht.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well said Scriuener, hast put'em all in: you shal heare now my L.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: In primis, the beuties of her minde, chastitie, temperance, and aboue all, pacience:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You haue bought a Iewell yfaith, my L, nine and thirtie, fortie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Excellent in the best of Musicke, in voice delicious: in conference wise and pleasing: of age contentful: neither too yong to be a pish, nor too old to be sottish

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You haue bought as louely a penny-woorth my Lord, as ere you bought in your life.

sp.speaker: Pro
sp.l: Why should I buy her else Captaine?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And which is the best, of a wife a most comfortable sweete companion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I could not affoord her so y faith, but that I am-going to sea and haue need of money.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A most comfortable sweete companion.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: What agen? the Scriuener reades in passion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I read as the words moue me: yet if that be a faul it shall be seen no more,— which said Madona Castiza lying, & yet being in the occupation of the said captain

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ninteene— occupation? Pox out, out with occupation, a Captaine is of no occupation, man.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Nor thou of no religion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now I come to the Habendum, to haue and to holde, vse and—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Vse? put out vse too for shame.
Till we are all gone, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And to be acquited of and from all former bargaines, former sales:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
Former sailes, nine & twenty thirty, by my troth
my Lord, this is the first time that euer I solde her.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Yet the writing must run so Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let it run on then, nine and fortie, fiftie,—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Former sales, Guiftes, Grants, Surrenders. Reentryes.—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: For Reentryes, I will not sweare for her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And furdermore (I the said) of and for the consideration of the somme of fiue hundred Crownes to set me a boord before these presents vtterly disclaime for euer, any Title, estate, right, interest, demaund, or possession, in or to the said Madona Castiza, my late vertuous, and vnfortunate wife.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Vnfortunate indeede, that was wel plac'd.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As also neither to touch, attempt, molest, or incumber any parte, or partes whatsoeuer: either to bee namde or not to be namde: eyther hidden or vnhidden, eyther those that boldly looke abroad, or those that dare not show their face.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faces: I knowe what you meane by faces: Scriuener, there's a great figure in faces.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: In witnesse wherof, I the said Captaine haue interchangeably set to my hand and seale: in presence of all these, the day and date aboue written.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Verie good sir, Ile bee ready for you presently, foure hundred and twentie. 1.2.3.4.5.—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Of all deedes, yet this strikes the deepest wound
Into my apprehension,
Reuerend, and honourable Matrimony,
Mother of lawfull sweetes, vnshamed mornings:
Dangerlesse pleasures, thou that mak'st the bed,
Both pleasant, and legitimately fruitfull: without thee,
All the whole world were soyled Bastardy.
Thou art the onely and the greatest forme.
That put'st a difference betweene our desires
And the disordered appetites of Beastes,
Making their mates, those that stand next their lusts.
Then,— with what base iniurie is thy goodnes paide
First, rare to haue a Bride commence a Maide,
But do's beguile ioy of the puritie:
And is made strickt by power of Drugs and Art,
An Artificall Maide, a Doctord Virgin,
And so deiceues the glorie of his bod:
A foule contempt, against the spotlesse power
Of sacred wedlocke, but if chast and honest,
There is another Deuill hauntes marriage,
(None fondly loues but knowes it) Iealousie,
That Wedlocks yellow sicknes, that whispering seperation euerie minute.
And thus the cursse takes his effect or progresse,
The moste of men in their first suddaine furyes,
Rayle at the narrow boundes of marriage,
And cal't a prison then it is moste iust,
That the disease 'ath prison, Ielousie
Should still affect a'm, but oh! here I am fixt,
To make sale of a wife, monstrous and foule,
An act abhord in nature, could in soule:
Who that ha's man in him, could so resigne,
To make his shame, the poesye to the Coyne?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Right yfaith, my Lord fully fiue hundred,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: I saide how you should finde it Captaine, and with this competent summe you rest amplye contented.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Amply contented.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Heere's the Pen Captaine: your name to the sale.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: S'foote doost take me to be a pen-man? I protest I could nere write more then A, B, C, those three letters in my life.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Why those will serue Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I could nere get furder.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Would you haue got furder then A B C? ah Base Captaine, that's far ynough yfaith.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Take the Seale off Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It goes on hardly, and comes off easily.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I iust like a Coward.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Will you write witnesse Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hee? he shall, prethe come and set thy hand for witnesse Rogue, thou shall venture with me?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, then I ha reason Captaine that commaunds me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What a faire fist the pretty whorsone writes, as if he had had manners and bringing vp, a farmers Sonne: his Father dam's himselfe to sell mustie Corne, while hee ventures the Money, twill prosper well at Sea no doubt he shall nere see't agein

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: So, Captaine you deliuer this as your deede.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As my deede, what else sir?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The ouglyest deed that ere mine eye did witnes

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: So my Lord, you haue her, clip her, enioy her, shee's your owne, and let me be proud to tell you now my Lord, shee's as good a soule if a man had a minde to liue honest, and keepe a wench, the Kindest, sweetest, comfortablest Rogue.—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Harke in thine eare,
The Baser slaue art thou: and so ile tell her,
I loue the Pearle, thou soldst, hate thee the Seller—
Goe, to Sea, the end of thee— is Lowsie.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: This fine worke: a verie braue end, hum—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wel thought vpon, this Scriuener may furnish me

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why should this fellowe be a Lord by birth?
Being by bloud a Knaue, one that would sell
His Lordship if he likt her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: What's here Now?

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: I haue imployment for a trustie fellow, bould, sure—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What if he be a Knaue my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p:
There thou comst to me, why he should be so,
and men of your quill are not vnacquainted.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed al our chiefe liuing my Lord, is by fooles and knaues, we could not keepe open shop else: Fooles that enter into bonds, and Knaues that binde e'm.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why now we meete.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And as my memorie happily leades me: I know a fellowe of a standing estate, neuer flowing: I durst conuey treason into his bosome,
sp.l: And keepe it safe nine yeares.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A goodly Time.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: And if neede were would presse to an attempt,
And cleaue to Desperate action.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: That Last fits mee.
Thou hast the measure right, looke I heare from thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: With duteous speede.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Expect a large reward:
I will finde time of her to finde regard.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The end of me is lowzie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Oh my Lord! I haue strange wordes to tell you.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Stranger yet? ile chuse some other hower to listen to thee, I am yet sicke of this, discouer quickly.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why, wil you make yourselfe knowne my Lord

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I.
Who scourgeth sinne let him doo't dreadfully.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pox of his dissemblance: I will to sea.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, you shall to sea, thou wouldst poyson the whole land else— why how now Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: In health.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What, drooping?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Or a shamde of the sale of thine owne wife?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You might count me an asse then yfaith.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: If not a sham'd of that, what can you be a shamd of then?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Prethe ha done, I am asham'd of nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I easily beleeue that.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This Lord stickes in my stomacke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How? take one of thy fethers downe, and fetch him vp.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ide make him come.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what if the Duke should heare of this?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I, or your Sonne in Law, Fidelio knowes of the sale of his mother.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What and they did, I sell none but mine owne: as for the Duke, hee's abroad by this time, and for Fidelio hee's in labour.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hee, in labour?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: What call you Trauelling?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: That's true:— but let me tell you Captain: whether the Duke heare on't, or Fidelio know on't: or both, or neither, twa's a moste filthie loathsome part.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: A base vnnaturall deede—

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: Slaue and foole:— ha, who? oh—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou hatefull villaine: thou shouldst chuse (to sincke
To keepe thy basenes shrouded.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ougly wretch.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: Who hath laid violence vpon my husband?
My deare sweet Captaine, helpe—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady you wrong your value,
Call you him deere that has solde you so cheape?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I do beseech your pardon good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Rise.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My abused Mother:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My kinde Sonne,
Whose liking I neglected in this match.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Not that alone, but you far happyer fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Is this the Scriuener and the Farmers Sonne,
Fire on his Lordship he tolde me they Trauaild.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And see the summe tolde out to buy that Iewel
More pretious in a Woman then her eye, her honour:
Nay take it to you Lady, and iudge it,
sp.p:
Too slight a recompence, for your great wrong, but that
his riddance helpes it.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: S'foot he vndoes me, I am a Rogue & a Beggar,
The Aegiptian plague creepes ouer me alreadie,
I begin to be lowsie.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Thus happily preuented, y'are set free,
Or else made ouer to adulterie.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: To heauen and to you my modest thankes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Monster, to sea, spit thy al horred foame,
Where it may doe least harme, ther's ayre and roeme.
Thour't Dangerous in a Chamber, Virulext Venem,
Vnto a Ladies name, and her chast breath
If past this euenings verge, the Dukedome hold thee,
Thou art reseru'd for abiect punishment.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: I doe beseech your good Lordship consider the state of a poore downe-cast Captaine.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Captaine, off with that noble title thou becomst it vildely, I nere saw the name fit worse, ile sooner allowe a Pandar a Captaine then thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: More's the pittie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sue to thy Lady for pardon.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I giue it without suite.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I do beseech your Ladiship not so much for pardon, as to bestow a few of those Crownes vpon a poore vnfethered Rouer that will as truely pray for you, and wish you hangd, as any man breathing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I giue it freely all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay by your fauour:
I will containe you Lady, here, be gone:
Vse slaues like slaues— wealth keepes their faults vnkowne.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well'ime yet glad, i'ue libertie and these:
The Land has plagu'd me, and ile plague the seas.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Sceane is cleer'd, the bane of brightnes fled
Who sought the death of honour, is strucke dead.
Come modest Lady:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: My moste honest mother.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thy vertue shall liue safe from reach of shames,
That Act endes nobly, preserues Ladies fames.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why this is but the second time of your comming Kinsman, visit me oftner, Daughter, I charge you bring this Gentleman along with you: Gentleman, I I crie yee mercy sir, I call you Gentleman still: I forget y'are but a Knight, you must pardon me sir.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: For your worships kindenes— worship I crie you mercie sir, I call you worshipfull still, I forget, y'are but a Iustice.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I am no more yfaith.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: You must pardon me sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Tis quickly done sir, you see I make bould with you Kinsman, thrust my Daughter and you into one Chamber.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Best of all sir: Kinred you knowe may lye anye where.

sp.speaker: Fals
sp.p: True, true sir, Daughter receiue your blessing— take heed the Coach iopper not to much, haue a care to the fruits of your bodye— looke to her Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Feare it not sir.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Nay Father though I say it, that should not say it, hee lookes to me more like a husband then a Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I heare good commendations of you sir.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: You heare the worst of me I hope sir,— I salute my leaue sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Y'are welcome all ouer your body sir: nay, I can behaue my selfe courtly, though I keepe house 'ith Countrie: what, does my Neece hide herselfe, not present, ha? Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Call my Neece to mee.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
A foolish, coy, bashfull thing it is, shee's afraid
to lie with her owne Vncle: ide do her no harme yfaith, I keepe my selfe a widdower a purpose, yet the foolish Girle will not looke into't, shee should haue all yfaith, shee knowes I haue but a time, cannot holde long, see where she comes, pray whome am I Neece?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I hope y'are your selfe.
Vncle to me, and Brother to my Father.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Oh am I so, it do's not appeare so,— for surely you would loue your Fathers Brother for your Fathers sake, your Vncle for your owne sake.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I doe so.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay you doe nothing Neece.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: In that loue which becomes you best I loue (you.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How should I know that loue becomes me best?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Because tis chast, and honorable.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Honorable! it cannot become me then Neece.
For 'ime scarce worshipfull: Is this an age,
To entertaine bare loue without the fruites
When I receiu'd thee first, I look't
Thou shouldst haue beene a wife vnto my house
And sau'd me from the charge of marriage.
sp.p: Do you thinke your Fathers fiue thousand pound wold ha made me take you else? no, you should neere a ha beene a charge to me.
sp.l: As far as I can perceiue yet by you,
sp.p: I'ue as much neede to marrie as ere I had: would not this be a greate griefe to your friendes thinke you, if they were aliue agen?

sp.speaker: Neece:
sp.l: Twould be a griefe indeede.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Y'aue confest
All about house, that young Fidelio
Who in his Trauailes does attend the Prince,
Is your vowde loue.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Most true, hee's my vow'd Husband.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
And what's a Husband is not a Husband a stranger at first, and wil you lye with a stranger before
you lie with your owne Vncle? take heede what yee doe Neece, I counsell you for the best: strangers are drunken fellowes I can tell you, they will come home late a nights, beate their wiues, and get nothing but Girles: look too't, if you marry, your stubbernes is your Dowrie: fiue thousand Crownes were bequeathed to you, true, if you marry with my consent: but if ere you goe to marrying by my consent, ile goe to hanging by your's: goe too, be wise and loue your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I should haue cause then to repent indeede.
Do you so far forget the Offices
Of blushing modestie? Vncles are halfe Fathers,
Why they come so neare our bloods th'are ene part of it.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why now you come to mee Neece: if your Vncle be part of your owne flesh and blood, is it not then fit your owne flesh and bloud should come neerest to you? answere me to that Neece.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You doe allude all to incestuous will,
Nothing to modest purpose: turne me foorth,
Be like an Vncle of these latter daies,
Periurde ynough, ynough vnnaturall,
Play your Executorship, in Tyranny,
Restraine my fortunes, keepe me poore, I care not,
In this alone moste women ile excell,
Ile rather yelde to beggery then to hell.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Very good, a my troth my Neece is Valiant, sha's made me ritcher by fiue thousand Crownes, the price of her Dowrie: are you so honest, I doe not feare but I shall haue the Conscience to keepe you poore ynough Neece, or else I am quite altered a late— The Newes, may it please you sir?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: Sir, theres an olde fellowe, a kinde of Law-driuer, entreates conference with your worship.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: A Law-driuer, prethee driue him hither.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: No, no I say if it bee for defect of Apparance, take me out a speciall Significauit.

sp.speaker: Whin.
sp.l: Verie good sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Then if he purchase an Alias or Capias, which are Writs of custome, onely to delay time, your Procedendo do's you Knights seruice— that's nothing at all, get your Distringas out as soone as you can for a Iurie.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ile attend your god worships comming out.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Do I prethee, attend me, ile take it kindly, a Voluntate.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What, old Seigneur Tangle!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I am in debt to your worships remembrance.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My old master of Fence: come, come, come, I haue not exerciz'd this twelue Moones, I haue almost forgot all my Law-weapons.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: They are vnder fine and Recouerie, your worship shall easily recouer them.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I hope so: when there?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: The Rapler and Dagger foyles instantly: and whats thy suite to mee olde Tangle, ile graunt it presently.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nothing but this sir, to set your worships hand to the commendation of a Knaue whome no bodye speakes well on.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: The more shame for e'm, what was his offence I pray?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Vestras Deducite Culpas— nothing but robbing a Vestrie.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
What, what! alasse poore Knaue, giue me the Paper, he did but saue the Churchwardens a labour: come, come, he has done a better deed in't then the parish is a aware off, to preuent the Knaues, hee robs but seldome, they once a quarter: me thinks twere a part of good iustice, to hang e'm at yeares end, wen they come out of
their office, to the true terrifying of all Collectors and Sidemen.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your worship would make a fruitefull Common-wealths man, the Constable lets e'm alone, looks on, and sayes nothing.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: A lasse good man, he lets e'm alone for quietnes sake, and takes halfe a share with e'm: they know wel enough too, he ha's an impediment in his tongue, hee's alwaies drunke when he should speake.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Indeede your worship speakes true in that sir: they blinde him with beere, and make him so narrowe eyde, that he wincks naturallye at all their Knaueries,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: So, so, heeres my hand to his commendations.

sp.speaker: Tangle.
sp.l: A Charitate, you doe a charitable deede in't sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, if it be but a Vestrie matter, visit me at anye time, olde Signeor Law-thistle! O well done, heere are the Foiles, come, come sir, ile trie a Law-bout with you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: I am affraide I shall ouerthrowe you sir yfaith.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Tis but for want of vse then sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Indeed that same odde word Vse, makes a man a good Lawyer, and a woman an arrant— tuh tuh, tuh, tuh, tuh, now am I for you sir: but first to bring you into forme, can your worship name all your weapons?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: That I can I hope, let me see, Longswoord, what's Longsword? I am so duld with dooing justice, that I haue forgot all yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Your long sword, thats a writ of delay.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Masse that swords long enough indeede, I ha knowne it reach the length of fifteene Tearmes.

sp.speaker: Tang
sp.l: Fifteene Tearmes, that's but a short sword.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Me thinkes tis long enough, proceede sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A Writ of Delay, Long-sword.
Scandala Magnatum, Backesword.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Scandals are back-swords indeede

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Capias cominus, Case of Rapyers.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Oh Desperate!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A Latitat, sword and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: A writ of Execution, Rapier and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Thou art come to our present weapon, but what call you sword and Buckler then?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh! that's out of vse now, sword and Buckler was cal'd a good conscience, but that weapons left long agoe, that was too manly a fight, too sound a weapon for these our daies, sl'id wee are scarce able to lift vp a Buckler now, our armes are so bound to the Poxe: one good bang vppon a Buckler would make moste of our Gentlemen flye a peeces, tis not for these lintie times, our Lawyers are good Rapyer and Dagger men, theile quickly dispatch your— money.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Indeede since sword and buckler time, I haue obseru'd, there ha's beene nothing so much fighting: where bee all our gallant Swaggerers? there are no good frayes alate.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh sir, the properties altred, you shall see lesse fighting euerie day then other, for euerie one gets him a Mistris, and she giues him woundes enowe, and you knowe, the Surgeons cannot bee here and there too, if there were red woundes too, what wold become of the Reinish woundes?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Thou saist true yfaith, they would bee but il favouredly lookt to then.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Verie well sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I expect you sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I lye in this court for you sir, my Rapyer is my Atturney, and my Dagger his Clarke.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Your Atturney wants a little oyling, me thinkes, he lookes very Rustily.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tis but his proper colour sir, his Father was an Iremonger, he will nere look brighter, the rust ha's so eat into him, ha's neuer any leasure to be made cleane.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Not in the vacation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Non Vacat exiguis rebus adesse Ioui.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Then Ioue will not be at leysure to scoure him, because he nere came to him before.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Y'are excellent at it sir— and now you least thinke on't, I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay very bad sir by my faith— I followe you still, as the Officers wil followe you as long as you haue a penny.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: You speake sentences sir— by this time haue I tryed my friendes, and now I thrust in baile—

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: This baile will not be taken sir, they must be two Cittizens that are no Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Berlady then 'ime like to lye by it, I had rather twere a hundred that were.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Take heede I bring you not to an Nisiprius sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I must ward my selfe as well as I may sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tis Court day now, Declarat Atturnatus, my Atturney gapes for money.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You shall haue no Aduantage yet, I put in my Answere.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I follow the sute still sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I like not this Court birlady— I: take me out a writ of Remoue, a writ of Remoue, doe you see sir?

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: And place my cause higher.

sp.speaker: Tang,
sp.p: There you started me sir— yet for all your Demurres, Plures, and Sursurarers, which are all Longswords: that's Delaies: al the comfort is, in nine yeares a man may ouerthrowe you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You must thanke your good friendes then sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Let nine yeares passe, fiue hundred crownes cast away a both sides, and the suite not twentie, my Counsellors wife must haue another hood you knowe, and my Atturneyes wife wil haue a new forepart, yet
see at length law, I shal haue law: now beware, I bring you to a narrowe exigent, and by no meanes can you auoide the Proclamation—

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now followes a writ of execution, a Capias, vt Legatum, giues you a wound mortall, trippes vp your heeles, and layes you ith Counter.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: O Villaine!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I crie your worship heartily mercie sir, I thought we had beene in Lawe together, Aduersarius contra aduersarium by my troth.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Oh! reach me thy hand, I nere had such an ouerthrowe in my life.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Twa's long of your Atturney there, hee might a staide the execution of Capias vt Legatum, and remou'd you with a Supersedeas non molestandum into the Court of Equitie.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Pox on him, he fell out of my hand when I had most neede of him,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I was bound to follow the suite sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou couldst doe no lesse then ouerthrowe me,
I must needes say so.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: You had recouered cost else sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: And now by'th masse I thinke I shal hardly recouer without cost.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Certoscio, an execution is very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Well, it shall teach mee witte as long as I am a Iustice: I perceiue by this tryall, if a man haue a sound fall in Law, hee shall feele it in his bones all his life after.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Recto vpon Record, for I my selfe was ouerthrowne in eighty eight by a Taylor, and I haue had a Stitch in my side euer since, oh!

div.stage: Toward the close of the musick, the Iustices three men prepare for a robberie.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why Latronello, Furtiuo, Fucato, where be these lazie knaues that should trusse me, not one stirring yet?

sp.speaker: A crie within.
sp.p: Followe, followe, followe.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What newes there?

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: This way, this way, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Hark you sluggish Soporiferous villaines, ther's knaues abroad when you are a bed, are ye not a sham'd on't, a Iustices men should be vp first, and giue example all knaues.

div.stage: Enter two of his men tumbling in, in False beards.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Oh I beseech your good worship.

sp.speaker: Fuca.
sp.l: Your worshipfull worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Theeues, my two hand sword, ime rob'd 'ith Hal, Latronello, Knaues, come down, my two hand sword I

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: I am Latronello, I beseech your worship, (say.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou Latronello, thou lyest, my men scorne to haue beardes.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: We forget our beards, now I beseech your worship quickly remember vs.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.l: Nay theres no time to talke of how now, tis don.

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: Foure marke and a Liuerie is not able to keepe life and soule together, wee must flye out once a quarte, tis for your worships credit to haue moneye in our pursse, our Fellow Furtiuo is taken in the Action.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A pox on him for a lazie knaue, would hee bee taken?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.p: They bring him along to your worship, your the next Iustice, now or neuer show your selfe a good maister, an vpright Magistrate, and deliuer him out of their hands.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, he shal finde me— apt enough to doe him good I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Latr:
sp.l: Hee comes in a false beard sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: S'foot what, should hee doe here else? there's no comming to me in a true on: if he had one,— the slaue to be taken: doe not I keepe Geldings swift enough?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: The goodlyest Geldings of any Gentleman in the shire.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Which did the whorson knaue ride vpon?

sp.speaker: Enter.
sp.l: Vpon one of your best sir.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: Stand and deliuer.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Vpon Stand and Deliuer: the verie Gelding I chuse for mine owne riding, as nimble as Pegasus the flying horse yonder: goe shift your selues into your coates, bring hither a great chaire, and a little table.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: With all present speede sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: And Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Sit you downe, & very soberly take the examination.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: Ile drawe a few horse heades in a paper, make a shew: I hope I shall keepe my countenence.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Pox on him agen, would he be taken? hee frets me: I haue beene a youth my selfe, I ha seene the day I could haue told money out of other mens purses (Masse so I can doe now) nor will I keepe that fellow about me that dares not bid a man stand: for as long as drunkennesse is a vice, stand is a vertue: but I would not haue 'em taken. I remember now betimes in a morning I would haue peept through the greene boughs, & haue had the partie presently, and then to ride away sinelye in feare, twas e'en Venerie to me yfaith, the pleasantst course of life, one would thinke euery Woodcok a Constable, and euery Owle an officer, but those dayes are past with mee: and a my troth I thinke I am a greater theefe now, and in no danger: I can take my ease, sit in my Chaire, look in your faces now, and rob you, make you bring your money by authoritie put off your hat, and thanke me for robbing of you, O there is nothing to a theefe vnder Couert Barne.

div.stage: Enter Phoenix, Fidelio being robd, Constable, Officers and the Theefe Furtino.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Come Officers bring him away.
