sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, I see thee through thy false beard, thou mid-winde chinde Rascall,
sp.l: How now my Maisters, whats he? ha?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Your worship knowes, I neuer come but I bring a theefe with me.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou hast left thy wont else Constable.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Sir, we vnderstand you to be the onely vp rightnes of this place.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: But I scare vnderstand you sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why then you vnderstand not your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Such another word, and you shal change places with the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A maintayner of equall causes I meane.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Now I haue you, proceede sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This Gentleman and my selfe, being led heather by occasion of businesse, haue beene offered the discurtesie of the Country, set vppon by three theeues and rob'd.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What are become of the other two, Latronello, and Fuca?

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: They both made away from vs, the crie pursues e'm, but as yet none but this taken.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Take his examination.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Let the Knaue stand single.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Thanke your good worship.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Ha's beene a suter at Court sure, hee thankes me for nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hee's a Theefe now sure.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: That we must know of him, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: A peece next to the Taile sir— a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
By my troth a prettie phrase and verye
cleanly handled, put it downe Latronello: thou mayst make vse on't. Is hee of honour or worship whom thou seruest?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Of both deere sir, honourable in minde, and worshipfull in bodie.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Why would one wish a man to speake better?

sp.speaker: Phoen
sp.l: Oh sir, they most commonly speake best, that doe worst.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Say you so sir, then weele trie him farther,— Do's your right worshipfull maister, goe before you, as an ensample of Vice, and so encourage you to this slinking iniquitie? hee is not a Lawer, is he?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Ha's the more wrong sir, both for his conscience, and honestie, he deserues to be one.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pittie hee's theefe yfaith, I should entertaine him else.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: I, if he were not as he is, hee would be better then himselfe.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: No tis well knowne sir, I haue a maister, the verie picture of wisdome,

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: For indeed he speakes not one wise worde.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And no man but will admire to heare of his Vertues.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Because he nere had any in all his life.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You write all downe Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: So sober, so discrete, so iudicious:

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And aboue all, of most reuerend grauitie.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I like him for one qualitie, hee speakes well of his maister, he will fare the better:— Now sir, let mee touch you,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
Why, seruing a Gentleman of such worship and wisdome, such sobrietie and vertue, such discretion and iudgement as your master is, doe you take such a beastly
course, to stop horses, hinder Gentlewomen from their meetings, and make Citizens neuer ride but a Sundaies, onely to auoyd Morning praier and you: is it because your worshipfull Ma. feeds you with leane spits, paies you with Irish mony, or clothes you in northern dozens?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Farre be it from his mind, or my report, Tis well knowne he kept worshipful cheer the day of his wiues burial, payes our foure marks a yeare as duly by twelue pence a quarter as can be.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: His wisdome swallowes it.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And for Northren dozens, fie, fie, wee were nere troubled with so many.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Receiuing then such plenteous blessings from your vertuous and bountiful master, what cause haue you to be theefe now? answer me to that geere:

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Tis ee'n as a man giues his mind too't sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: For alas, if the whole worlde were but of one trade; traffique were nothing: if wee were all truemen, wee should bee of no trade: what a pittifull world would heere bee, heauen forbid we should bee all truemen: then howe should your worships next suite bee made? not a Tayler left in the lande: of what stuffe would you haue it made? not a Merchant left to deliuer it, would your worship goe in that sute still? You would ha more theeues about you then those you haue banisht, and be glad to call the great ones home agen, to destroy the little.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A notable Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A my troth, a fine knaue, & ha's answered me gloriously, what wages wilt thou take after thou art hang'd?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: More then your worship's able to giue, I would thinke foule scorne to be a Iustice then.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: He sayes true too yfayth, for we are all full of corruption here,— hearke you my friends.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: By my troth if you were no crueller then I, I could find in my hart to let him goe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Could you so sir, the more pittiful Iustice you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay I did but to trie you, if you haue no pittie, Ile ha none, away hee's a Theefe, to prison with him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: I am content sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Are you content, bring him backe, nay then you shall not goe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile be as cruel as you can wish: y'are content, belike you haue a tricke to breake prison, or a bribe for the Officers.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: For vs sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: For you sir? what colour's siluer I pray, you nere saw mony in your life:— Ile not trust you with him, Latronello and Fucato, lay hold vpon him, to your charge I commit him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Oh, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Nay if I must be cruell, I will be cruell.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Good sir, let me rather goe to prison.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You desire that,— Ile trust no prison with you, Ile make you lye in mine own house, or Ile know why I shal not.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Mercifull sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Since you haue no pittie I will be cruell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Verie good sir, you please vs well.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You shall appeare to morrow sirs.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Vpon my knees sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You shall be hang'd out a'th way, away with him Latronello, and Fucato,— Officers I discharge you my house, I like not your companie.
sp.l: Report me as you see me, fire and fuell,
If men be Iewes, Iustices must be cruell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: So sir, Extreames set of all Actions thus,
Eyther too tame, or else too tyranous:
He being bent to furie, I doubt now
We shall not gaine accesse vnto your loue or she to vs.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Most wishfully here she comes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Is that shee?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: This is she my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A modest presence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Vertue blesse you Ladie,

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You wish me well sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I'de first in charge this kisse, and next this paper,
You'le know the language, tis Fidelios.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: My euer vowed loue, how is his health?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: As faire as is his fauour with the Prince.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: I'me sick with ioy, do's the Prince loue him so?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: His life cannot requite it,
Not to wrong the remembrance of his loue,
I had a token for you, kept it safe,
Till by misfortune of the way this morning,
Theeues set vpon this Gentleman and my selfe,
And with the rest robd that.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Oh me, I'me deerly sorie for your chance, was it your losse?
They boldly looke you in the face that rob'd you,
No farther villaines then my vncles men.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What Ladie?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Tis my griefe I speake so true.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why my Lord?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But giue me pawsing Lady: was hee one that tooke the examination?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: One and the chiefe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hence-forth hang him that is no way a theefe,
sp.p: Then I hope few will suffer,— nay all the iest was, hee committed him to the charge of his fellowes, and the rogue made it lamentable, cryed to leaue'em.
sp.l: None liue so wise but fooles may once deceiue em?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: An vncle so insaciate?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I, Ist not strange too,
That al should be by Nature vicious, and he bad against
Nature?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Then you haue heard the sum of al my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady, we haue, and desire rather now
To heale 'em, then to heare 'em:
For by a letter from Fidelio
Direct to vs, we are entreated ioyntly,
To hasten your remoue from this foule den,
Of theft and purpos'd incest:

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I reioyce in his chast care of mee, Ile soone bee furnisht.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He writes that his returne cannot be long.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I'me chiefly glad,— but whither is the place?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: To the safe seate of his late wronged mother.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I desire it,—
Her conference will fit mine, well you preuaile,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: At next groue weele expect you:

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Ile not faile.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: It stands vpon the frame of my reputation I protest Ladie.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Ladie, that worde is worth an hundred Angels at all times, for it cost more: if I liue til tomorrow night, my sweete pleasure thou shalt haue them.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Could you not make 'em a hundred and fiftie thinke you?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Ile do my best endeuour to multiply, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Could you not make 'em two hundred?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No by my faith.—

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.l: Peace, ile rather be confin'd in the hundred & fifty.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Come ee'n much about this time, when Tauerns giue vp their Ghosts, and Gentlemen are in their first cast.—

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Ile obserue the season.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
And doe but whirle the Ring a'th doore once about,
my maid-seruant shal be taught to vnderstand the language.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Inough my sweet Reuenew.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Good rest my effectuall pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Come hither Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What makes your honour breake so earely?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A toy, I haue a toy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A toy my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Before thou layest thy wrath vpon the duke,— be aduiz'd.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: I, I, I warran you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Nay, giue my words honour, heare me,
Ile striue to bring this Act into such forme,
And credite amongst men, they shall suppose.
Nay verily beleeue the Prince his sonne,
To be the plotter of his Fathers murther.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Oh that were infinitely admirable!

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Wert not, it pleaseth me beyond my blisse:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Then if his sonne meet death as he returnes,
Or by my hired Instruments turne vp,
The generall voice will crie— O happy vengeance!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O blessed vengeance!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, ile turn my braine
Into a thousand vses, Tire my inuentions,
Make my blood sicke with studie, and mine eye
More hollow then my heart, but I will fashion,
Nay I will fashion it,— Canst counterfet?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Princes hand, more truly, most direct,
You shall admire it.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Necessarie mischiefe.
Next to a woman, but more close in secrets
Thou'rt all the kinred that my breast vouchsafes,
Looke into me anon,— I must frame, and muse, and
fashion—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twas time to looke into thee, in whose heart
Treason growes ripe, and therefore fit to fall,
That slaue first sinkes, whose enuie threatens all,
Now is his Venom at full height.

sp.speaker: 1 Voic.
sp.p: Lying, or being in the said Countie in the Tenor and occupation aforesaide.

sp.speaker: 2 Voyce.
sp.p: No more then, a writ of course vpon the matter of—

sp.speaker: 3. Voice.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: 4. Voice.
sp.p: Oh o-o-o-yes Carlo Turbulenzo, appeare or loose twentie marke in the suites.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Ha? whether haue my thoughts conueyed me? I am now within the Dizzie murmur of the law.

sp.speaker: 1 Voyce.
sp.p: So that then, the cause being found cleere, vpon the last Scitation.

sp.speaker: 4 Voice.
sp.l: Carlo turbulenzo, Come into the Court.

div.stage: Enter Tangle w̄ith two after him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now, now, now, now, now, vpon my knees I praise Mercury the God of law, I haue two suits at issue, two suites at issue.

sp.l: Doe you heare sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I wil not heare, i'ue other busines.
I beseech you my learned Counsell.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Beseech not me, beseech not me, I am a mortall man, a Clyent as you are, beseech not me.
I would doe all by your worships direction.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Then hang thy selfe.
Shall I take out a speciall supplycauit.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Mad me not, torment me not, teare me not, youle giue me leaue to heare mine own cause, mine owne cause

sp.speaker: 1. Voice.
sp.p: Nay moreouer, and farder—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Well said my Lawyer, well saide, well saide.

sp.speaker: 1. Voice.
sp.p: All the opprobious speeches that man could inuent all malicious inuectiues, called Wittoll to his face.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Thats I, thats I, thank you my learned counsell for your good remembrance: I hope I shall ouerthrowe him horse and foote.

sp.l: Nay but good sir.

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: No more sir, he that brings me happy newes first ile releeue first.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Sound executions rot thy cause and thee.

sp.speaker: Ta:
sp.p: I, I, I, pray so still, pray so still, theile thriue the better

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I wonder how this fellow keepes out madnes?
What stuffe his braines are made on?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I suffer, I suffer,— till I here a iudgement.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What old Signior?

sp.speaker: Tan
sp.p: Prethee I will not knowe thee nowe, tis a busie time, a busie time with me.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What not me Signeur?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh crie thee mercie, giue me thy hande,— fare thee well,— ha's no reliefe agen mee then,— his demurs will not help him, his Sursararaes wil but play the knaues with him.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: The Iustice: tis hee

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Haue I found thee yfaith? I thought where I should smell thee out old Tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: What old Signeur Iusticer,— embrace me another time and you can possible: how do's all thy wiues children,— well? that's well said yfayth.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Heare me olde Tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Prethee doe not rauish me, let me goe.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I must vse some of thy counsaile first.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ha brought him to an Exigent, hark that's my cause, thats my cause yonder, I twind'g him, I twind'g him.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My Neece is stolne away.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah, get mee a ne exeat Regno quickly, nay you must not stay vppo'nt, Ide faine haue you gone.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: A ne exeat Regno, ile about it presently,— adue.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: You seeke to catch her Iustice, sheele catch you.
A iudgement, a iudgement.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: What, what, what?
Ouerthrowne, ouerthrowne, ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Ha, a, a.
Newes, newes, newes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: The diuell, the diuell, the diuell.
Twice Tangle's ouerthrowne, twice Tangles ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Holde:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now olde cheater of the Law,

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Pray giue me leaue to bee madde.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
Thou that hast found such sweete pleasure in
the vexation of others.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: May I not be mad in quiet?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Very Marrow, very manna to thee to be in law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Very sirrop of Toades, and perseru'd Adders.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou that hast vext, and beggerd the whole
Parrish, and made the honest Church wardens goe to
Lawe with the poores money.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Heare me, doe but heare me, I pronounce a terrible, horrible cursse vpon you al— and wish you to my Atturney: see where a Praemunire comes a Dedimus potestatem, and that moste Dreadful Execution, Excommunicato Capiendo, there's no baile to be taken, I shal rot in fifteene Iayles: make Dice of my bones, and let my Counsellors Sonne play away his Fathers money with e'm; may my bones reuenge my quarrell!— A Capias Cominus? heere, heere, heere, heere: quicklye dip your Quilles in my blood, off with my skin and write fourteen lines of a side— there's an honest conscionable fellowe, he takes but ten shillinges of a Bellowes-mender— heere's another deales all with charitie, you shall giue him nothing, onely his wife an embrodered Petty-coate, a golde frindge for her taile, or a border for her head, ah sirrha! you shall catch mee no more in the sprindge of your Knaueries.
Follow, follow him still, a little thing now sets him forward.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: None can except against him, the mans mad,
And priuiledgd by the Moone, if he say true:
Lesse madnes tis to speake sinne, then to doe.
This wretch that lou'd before, his foode, his strife,
This punishment falles euen with his life.
His pleasure was vexation, all his blisse
The torment of another.
Their heart, his health: their starued hopes his store,
Who so loues Law, dies either mad or poore.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A miracle, a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How now Fidelio?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What ist?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I haue found
One quiet, suffering, and vnlawyer'd man.
An opposite, a very Contrarie
To the olde turbulent fellowe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why hee's mad.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Mad, why he is in his right wits, could he be madder then he was, if he be any way altered from what hee was, tis for the better, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well, but where's this wonder?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Tis comming my Lord: A man so truely a man, so indifferently a creature, vsing the world in his right nature but to tread vppon, one that would not bruse, the cowardly est enemy to man, the worme, that dares not show his malice till we are dead: nay my Lord, you will admire his temper! see where he comes, I promisd your acquaintance, sir
sp.l: Yon is the Gentleman I did commend for Temper.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Let me embrace you simply.
That's perfectly, and more in heart then hand:
Let affectation keepe at Court.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I, let it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Tis told me you loue quiet

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Aboue wealth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I aboue life: I haue been wilde and rash
Committed many and vnnaturall crimes,
Which I haue since repented.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twa's well spent.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I was mad, starke mad, nine yeares together.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I pray! as how?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Going to law, yfaith it made me mad.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: With the like frenzie not an houre since
An aged man was strucke.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Alasse I pittie him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Hee's not worth pittying, for twa's stil his gladnes to be at variance.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Yet a mans worth pittie,
My quiet blood ha's blest me with this guift,
I haue cur'd some, and if his wits be not
Too deepely cut, I will assay to helpe e'm.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sufferance does teach you pittie.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Maister, Maister, your abhominable next neighbor came into the house, being halfe in drink, and tooke away your best Carpet.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Has hee it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alasse sir:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Let him goe, trouble him not, lock the doore quietly after him, and haue a safer care who comes in next.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: But sir, might I aduize you, in such a cause as this, a man might bouldlye, nay with conscience goe to Law.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Oh, ile giue him the table too first. Better indure a fist then a sharpe sword: I had rather they should pull off my cloathes then flea of my skin, and hang that on mine enemies hedge.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why, for such good causes was the law ordaind:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: True, and in it selfe tis glorious and deuine,
Law is the verie Maister peece of heauen:
But see yonder.
Ther's many Clowdes betweene the sunne and vs,
There's too much cloath before we see the Law:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'me content with that answere, be milde still,
Tis honour to forgiue those you could kill.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: There doe I keepe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Reach me your hand, I loue you,
And you shall knowe me better.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Tis my sute.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The night growes deepe— and—

sp.speaker: 1 Off:
sp.l: Come away, this way, this way.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Who be those? stand close a little.

div.stage: Iars the Ring of the Doore, the Maide enters catches him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh, y'are come as well as ere you came in your life, my Maister's new gone to bed, giue me your Knightly hand, I must leade you into the blind Parlor, my mistris will be downe to you presentlye.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: I tell you our safest course will bee to arrest him when hee comes out a'th Tauerne: for then he will bee halfe drunke, and will not stand vppon his weapon.

sp.l: Our safest course indeede, for hee will drawe.

sp.p: That he will, though he put it vp agen, which is more of his courtesie, then of our deseruing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: The world is nothing but vexation,
Spite and vncharitable Action.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Did you see the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Where should he be, it may be hee's past by,
Good sir, lets ouertake him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here sir, now you are there sir, sheele come downe to you instantlye, I must not stay with you, my Mistris would be iealous, you must doe nothing to me, my mistris would finde it quickly.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: S'foot whether am I led? brought in byth hand? I hope it can bee no harme to stay for a woman, tho indeede they were neuer more dangerous, I haue ventured heatherto and safe, and I must venture to stay now, this should be a faire Rome, but I see it not, the blinde Parlor cal's shee it?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Where art thou, O my Knight!

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Your Knight, I am the Dukes knight.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I say you'r my knight, for I'me sure I paid for you

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Paid for you hum,— S'foot a light.—

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Now out vpon the Marmoset, hast thou seru'd me so long, and offer to bring in a Candle?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Faire Roome, villanous face, and worse woman, I ha learnt something by a glimpse ath Candle:

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: How hapned it you came so soone, I lookt not for you these two howers: yet as the sweete chance is, you came as well as a thing coulde come, for my husband's newly brought a bed.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And what ha's Ioue sent him?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Hee nere sent him any thing since I knewe him, hee's a man of a bad nature to his wife, none but his Maides can thriue vnder him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Out vpon him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I, iudge whether I haue a cause to be a Curtezan or no? to doe as I doe, an elderly fellow as hee is, if hee were marryed to a young Virgin, hee were able to breake her heart, tho he could breake nothing else: here, here, there's iust a hundred and fiftie, but I stole e'm so hardlye from him, twold ee'ne haue grieud you to haue seene it.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: So twould yfaith.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Therefore prethee my sweete pleasure, doe not keepe company so much, how doe you thinke I am able to maintaine you? though I bee a Iewellers wife, Iewells are like women, they rise & fal, we must be content to loose sometimes, to gaine often, but you'r content alwaies to loose, and neuer to gaine: what need you ride with a Footeman before you?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Oh thats the grace,

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: The grace? tis sufficient grace that y'aue a Horse to ride vpon, you should thinke thus with your selfe euery time you goe to bed if my head were laide, what would become of that horse? he would runne a bad race then as well as his Maister.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay, and you giue me money to chide me:—

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: No, if it were as much more, I would thinke it foule scorne to chide you, I aduise you to be thrifty, to take the time now, while you haue it, you shall sildome get such an other foole as I am, I warrant you: why there's Mettrezza Auriola keepes her loue with halfe the cost that I am at, her friend can goe a foote like a good Husband, walke in wosted Stockings, and enquire for the Six-penny ordinarie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Pox on't, and would you haue me so base?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: No, I would not haue you so base neither: but now and then, when you keep your Chamber, you might let your Footeman out for eighteen pence a day, a great releefe at yeares end I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: The age must needs be foule when vice reformes it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Nay, I'ue a greater quarrell to you yet.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Yfaith, what ist?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: You made me beleeue at first the Prince had you in great estimation, and would not offer to Trauaile without you, nay, that he could not trauaile without your Direction and intelligence.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'me sorrie I saide so yfaith, but sure I was ouerflowen when I spoke it, I could nere ha saide it else.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Nay more, you swore to me, that you were the first that taught him to ride a greate horse, and tread the Ring with agilitie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: By my troth I must needes confesse I swore a great lye in that, & I was a villain to doe it, for I could nere ride greate horse in my life.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p:
Why loe, who would loue you now but a Cittizens wife? so inconstant, so for sworne: you say women are false Creatures, but take away men, and thei'd bee honester then you— Nay last of all, which offends me moste of all, you tolde me you covld countenance me at Court, and you knowe wee esteeme a friend there, more
worth then a Husband heere.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What I spake of that. Lady, ile maintaine.

sp.speaker: Iew:
sp.l: You maintaine? you seene it court?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why by this Diamond—

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Oh take heede, you cannot haue that, tis alwaies in the eye of my husband.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I protest I will not keepe it, but onely vse it for this vertue, as a token to fetch you, & approue my power, where you shall not onely ye bee receiued, but made knowne to the best and chiefest.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.l: Oh are you true?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Let me loose my Reuenewe else.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p: That's your word indeede, and vppon that condition take it this kisse and my loue for euer.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ynough.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Giue me thy hand, ile leade thee foorth.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'me sicke of al professions, my thoughts burne:
He trauailes best, that knowes when to returne.

div.stage: Enter Knight, two Officers after him.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Adue, farwell, to bed you, I to my sweete Cittybird, my precious Reuennew, the verie thought of a hundred & fiftie Angels, encreases Oyle and Spirit, ho:

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: You haue made vs wayte a goodly time for you, haue you not thinke you? you are in your Rowses & Mulwines a poxe on you: and haue no care of poore Officers staying for you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I drunk but one health I protest, but I could void it now: at whose sute I pra'y?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: At the sute of him that makes suits, your Taylor,

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Why, he made me the last, this, this that I weare

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p:
Argo, nay, we haue bene Schollars I can tell you, wee could not haue beene knaues so soone else, for as in that notable Cittie cald London, stand two most famous Vniuersities, Poultrie and Woodstreet, where some are of
twentie yeares standing, and haue tooke all their degrees from the Maisters side, downe to the Mistris side, the Hole, so in like manner—

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p: Come, come, come, I had quite forgot the hundred and fiftie Angells.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: S'lid where be they?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Ile bring you to the sight of e'm presently.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: A notable Lad, and worthy to be arrested: weele haue but ten for wayting, and then thou shalt chuse whether thou wilt runne away from vs, or wee from thee.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: A match at running, come, come, followe me.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Nay, feare not that.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Peace, you may happen to see toyes, but doe not see e'm.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Pah.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Thats the Doore.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: This?— knockes.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Sfoote Officer you haue spoilde all already?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p: Why? you shall see, you should haue but whirld the ring once about, and there's a Maid seruant brought vp to vnderstand it.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.l: Whos's at doore?

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Als well againe: phist, tis I, tis I.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: You, what are you?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Puh, where's thy mistris?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Knigh.
sp.l: Tell her One, she knowes who, her Pleasure's heere, say.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Her Pleasure? my mistris scornes to be without her pleasure at this time of night: is shee so voide of friendes thinke you? take that for thinking so: a Boxe

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: The hundred and fifty Angells are lockt vp in a Boxe, we shall not see e'm tonight.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p:
Howe's this? am I vsde like a hundred pound
Gentleman? Do's my Reuennew forsake me? Dam me if euer I bee her pleasure agen.— Well I must to prison.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Goe prepare his roome, there's no remedie, ile bring him along, hee's tame enough now.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Dare my Tailor presume to vse me in this sort?
He steales and I must lie in prison for't.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Come, come away sir.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman with a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Art sure thou sawest him arested Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: If mine eyes be sober.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And that's a question, Masse here he goes, hee shall not goe to prison, I haue a tricke shall baile him— away.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Gesse, gesse, who am I? who am I?

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Who the Diuell are you? let goe,— a Poxe on you, who are you? I haue lost my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Prisoner: I'ue mistooke, I crie you heartily mercie, I haue done you infinite iniurie, a my troth I tooke you to be an honest man.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Where were your eyes? could you not see I was an Officer, stop, stop, stop, stop.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Now Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Let princely blood
Nourish our hopes, we being confusion now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A terrible suddaine blow.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I: what day is this hangs ouer vs?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: byth Masse Monday.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: As I could wish my purpose will thriue best.
Twa's first my birthday, now my fortunes daie,
I see whome fate will raise needes neuer pray.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: How is the ayre?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh full of trouble.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Do's not the skie looke pittiously blacke

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: As if twere hung with Rich mens Consciences.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Ah, Stucke not a Comet like a Carbuckle
Vpon the dreadfull browe of Twelue last night?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twelue, no twa's about one.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: About one most proper, for thats the Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well shifted from thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I could haue wisht it betweene one and two
His sonne and him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ile giue you comfort then.

sp.speaker: Prod,
sp.l: Prethee.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: There was a villanous Rauen seene last night,
Ouer the presence chamber in hard Iustle
With a yong Eglet.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A Rauen! that was I, what did the Rauen?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Mary my Lord the Rauen— to say truth,
I left the combat doubtfull.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: So tis still,
For all is doubt, till the deed crowne the will,
Now blesse thy loynes with Freedome, wealth and honour,
Think all thy seede young Lords, and by this Acte.
Make a foote-cloathd posteritie: now imagine
Thou seest thy Daughters with their traines borne vp,
Whome else despised want, may cursse to whoredome,
And publike shames, which our state neuer threate,
Shee's neuer lew'd, that is accounted great.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ile alter that Court-Axiom, thus renewd,
Shee's neuer great, that is accounted lewde.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Stand close, the presence fils, heere, heere the place
And at his rizing, let his fall be base,
Beneath thy foote.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How for his Guard my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: My golde and feare keepes with the chiefe of them

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That's rarely well.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Bould heedlesse slaue, that dares attempt a deede which shall in peeces rend him my Lords both.

div.stage: Enter Lussurioso, and Infesto two Lords.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: The happinesse of the day.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Time my returning,
Treasons haue still the worst, yet still are spurning.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: The Duke!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I nere was gladder to beholde him.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: All. Long liue your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do not like that straine,
You know my age affoords not to liue long.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Spoke truer then you thinke for.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bestow that wish vpon the Prince our Sonne.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: Nay, hee's not to liue long neither.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Him as the wealthie Treasure of our hopes,
You as posession of our present Comfort,
Both in one heart, we reuerence in one.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh Treason of a good complexion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now, what fresher newes fils the Courts eare?

sp.speaker: Prod,
sp.l: Fidelio!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Glad Tydings to your Grace,
The prince is safe return'd, and in your Court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our ioy breakes at our eyes, the Prince is come!

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Soule quicking newes— pale vengeance to my blood.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: By me presenting to your serious view,
A briefe of all his Trauailes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Tis most welcome.
It shall be Deere and pretious to our Eye.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Hee Reades, i'me glad her reades.
Now take thy opportunitie, leaue that place.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: At hys first rising let his fall be base.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: That must be altered now.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Which? his rising or his fall?

sp.speaker: rod.
sp.l: Art thou dull now?
Thou hear'st the Prince is come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's heere my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have got such a large portion of knowledge, most worthy father, by the benefit of my Trauaile,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And so he has no doubt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That I am bolde now to warne you of Lord
sp.p: Proditors insolent Treason, who has irreligiouslye seduc'd a fellow, and closely conuaide him ee'n in the presence-chaire to murder you:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Oh guiltie, guiltie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What was that fell? whats hee?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am the man.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: O slaue!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I haue no power to strike,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I'me gone, i'me gone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let me admire heauen's wisdome in my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I confesse it, he hyred me—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: This is slaue,
Tis forg'd against mine honour and my life,
For in what part of reason can't appeare,
The Prince being Trauaild should know Treasons heere
Plaine counterfet—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Doost thou make false our Sonne?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I know the prince will not affirme it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He can and will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Most iust, he may:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A guard.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: We cannot but in loyall zeale our selues,
Lay hands on such a Villaine.—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay you, I finde you heere too.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Vs my Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Against Lussurioso and Infesto, who not onelye moste ryotouslye consume their houses in vicious gaming, morgaging their liuings to the Merchant, wherby he with his heires enter vppon their lands, from whence this abuse comes, that in short time the Sonne of the Marchant has more Lordships then the Sonne of the Nobleman (which else was neuer borne to inheritance) but that which is more impious, they most adulterously traine out young Ladyes to Mid-night banquets, to the vtter defamation of their owne honors, & ridiculous abuse of their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: How could the Prince heare that?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Most true my Lord.
My Conscience is a witnesse gainst it selfe,
For to that execution of chast honour,
I was both hyr'd and led.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I hope the Prince out of his plentious wisdome
Will not giue wrong to vs: as for this fellowe
Hee's poore, and cares not to be desperate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Iustice my Lord, I haue my Neece stolne from me
Sh'as left her Dowrie with me, but shee's gone,
Ide rather haue had her loue then her money I,
This, this, is one of them, Iustice my Lord:
I know him by his face, this is the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Your grace may now in milder sence perceiue
The wrong done to vs by this impudent wretch,
Who ha's his hand fixt at the throate of lawe,
And therefore durst be desperate of his life,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Peace, you'r too foule, your crime is in excesse:
One spot of him, makes not your Vlcers lesse.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.l: Did your Violence force away his Neece?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: No my good Lord; Ile stil confesse whats truth.
I did remoue her from her many wrongs,
Which shee was pleasd to leaue, they were so vilde.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are you nam'd?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Falso my Lord, Iustice Falso, i'me knowne by that name.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Falso, you came fitly,
You are the verie next that followes here.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I hope so my Lord, my name is in all the Records
I can assure your good grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Against Iustice Falso.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who hauing had the honest charge of his Neece committed to his trust, by the last will and Testament of her deceased father, and with her all the power of his wealth, not onely against faith and conscience detaines her Dowrie, but against Nature and humanity assaies to abuse her body.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I'me present to affirme it my lou'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How? what make I heere?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Eyther I must agree.
To loathed lust, or despisde beggery.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are you the plaintiue here?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I my good Lord,
For fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Sildome comes a worse— and moreouer not containde in this vice onelye, which is odious to much, but against the sacred vse of Iustice, maintaines three threeues to his men.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Cuds me!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who onely take Pursses in their Maisters libertie, where if any one chance to be taken, he appeares before him in a false Beard, and owne of his owne fellows takes his examination.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: By my troth as true as can be, but hee shall not knowe on't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
And in the end will execute Iustice so cruellye vpon him, that hee will not trust him in a prison, but
commit him to his fellowes chamber.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Can a man doe nothing i'the Countrey but tis told at Court? there's some busie informing knaue abroad, a my life.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That this is true, and these, and more my Lord.
(Be it vnder pardon spoken for mine owne)
Hee the disease of Iustice, these of honour,
And This of Loyaltie and Reuerence:
The vnswept venome of the Pallace,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Slaue!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Behold the Prince to approoue it.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh, where?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Your Eyes keep with your Actions, both looke wrong.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: An infernall to my spirit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My Lord the Prince:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Tread me to dust, thou in whom wonder keepes,
Behold the Serpent on his bellie creepes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Ranckle not my foote, away.
Treason, we laugh at thy vain-labouring strings,
Aboue the foote thou hast no power ore Kings

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot with sufficient ioy receiue thee,
And yet my ioye's too much,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: My royall Father,
To whose vnnaturall murther I was hir'd,
I thought it a more naturall course of trauaile,
And answering future expectation,
To leaue farre Countryes, and enquire mine owne,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: To thee let Reuerence all her powers engage,
That art in youth a myracle to age.
State is but blindness, ethou hadst piercing Art,
We onely saw the knee; but thou the heart.
To thee then power and Dukedome we resigne,
, Hee's fit to raign, whose knowledge can refine:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Forbid it my obedience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our word's not vaine,
I know thee wise can'st both obey and raigne,
The rest of life we dedicate to heauen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A happy and safe raigne to our new Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Without your praiers safer, & happier: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My royall Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Here take this Diamond:
You know the vertue on't, it can fetch vice:
Madam Castiza:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: She attends my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Place a guard neare vs.
Know you you fellow Ladie?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: My honours euill.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Torment agen?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So vgly are thy crimes,
Thine eye cannot endure 'em.
And that thy face may stand perpetually
Turn'd so from ours, and thy abhorred selfe,
Neither to threaten wracke of state or credite,
An euerlasting banishment ceaze on thee.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh Fiend!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Thy life is such it is too bad to end.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: May thy Rule, life, and all that's in thee glad,
Haue as short time— as thy begetting had.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Away, thy curse is idle, the rest are vnder reformation, and therefore vnder pardon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our duties shall turne edge vpon our crimes.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: S'lid I was afraid of nothing, but that for my theeuerie, and bawderie I should haue beene turnd to an Inkeeper: my daughter, I am asham'd her worship should see mee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Who would not loue a friend at Court? what fine Galleries and roomes am I brought through? I had thoght my knight durst not haue shown his face here, I.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Now mother of pride, and daughter of lust, which is your friend now?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'me sure you are not so vnprouided to be without a friend here, you'le pay enough for him first.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: This is the worst roome that euer I came in.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am your seruant Mistris, know you not me!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Your worship is to great for me to know: I'me but a small timbred-woman when I'me out of my apparell, and dare not venture vpon greatnes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Doe you denie me then? know you this purse?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: That purse? O death has the Knight seru'd me so? giuen away my Fauours?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stand forth— thou one of those, for whose close lusts the plague neuer leaues the Citie.
Thou worse then common: priuate, subtill harlot,
That dost deceiue Three with one faigned lip,
Thy husband, the worlds eye, and the lawes whip.
Thy zeale is hot, for tis to lust and frawde,
And dost not dread to make thy booke thy Bawde,
Thou'rt cursse enough to husbands il-got gaines,
For whom the Court reiects, his gold maintaines:
How deere and rare was Freedome wont to be,
Now few but are by their wiues copies free,
And brought to such a head that now we see,
Citie and Suburbs weare one liuerie.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Tis long of those, an't like your grace, that come in vpon vs, & wil neuer leaue marrying of our widdows till they make 'em all as free as their first husbands.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I perceiue you can shift a point well.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Let me haue pardon I beseech your grace, and Ile peach 'em all, all the close women that are, and vpon my knowledge there's aboue fiue thousand within the walls and the liberties.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: A band? they shall be sent against the Turke, Infidels against Infidels.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I will hereafter liue so modestly, I will not lie with mine owne husband, nor come neere a man in the way of honestie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ile be her warrant my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd, you thinke y'are stil a Iustice.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: S'foot, worse then I was before I kneeld, I am no Iustice now, I know I shall be some Inne-keeper at last.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My father! tis mine owne father.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I should haue wondred else, lust being so like.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.p: Her birth was kin to mine, she may proue modest, for my sake I beseech you pardon her.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: For thy sake Ile doe more, Fidelio hand her,
My fauours on you both, next all that wealth
Which was committed to that Periur'ds trust.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I'me a begger now, worse then an Inne-keeper.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your Mittimus shall not serue, Ile set my selfe free with a Deliberandum, with a Deliberandum, marke you:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's he? a guard!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Vnder your sufferance, worthy Father,
His harme is to himselfe,
One that ha's lou'd vexation so much,
He cannot now be rid on't,
Has beene so long in suits that hee's Law-mad.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A iudgement, I craue a iudgement, yea! Nunc pro tunc, Corruptione alicuius, I peept me a Rauen in the face, and I thought it had beene my Solister: oh the pens pricke me.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: And here comes he (wonder for temperance:)
Will take the cure vpon him.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: A blessing to this faire assembly.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Away, Ile haue none ont, giue me an Audita querela, or a Testificandum, or a dispatch in twelue Tearms, there's a blessing, there's a blessing.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You see the vnbounded rage of his disease,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: Tis the foule fiend my Lord ha's got within him the rest are faire to this, this breeds in Inke,
sp.l: And to that colour turnes the blood possest,
For instance, now your grace shall see him drest.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah hah I reioice then hee's puzled, & muzled too Ist come to a Soepe corpus?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Ah, good sir, this is for want of patience.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: That's a foole.
She neuer saw the Dogs and the Beares fight,
A Countrey thing.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: This is for lacke of grace,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I'ue other businesse, not so much idle time.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: You neuer say your prayers.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I'me, aduizde by my learned counsel,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The power of my charme come o're thee,
Place by degrees thy wits before thee,
With silk en patience here I binde thee,
Not to moue till I vnwinde thee.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Yea! is my cause so muddy? do I sticke, do I sticke (fast?
Aduocate heer's my hand, pull, art made of flint?
Wilt not helpe out?— alas there's nothing in't.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Oh doe you sluce the Veyne now?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Yes my honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Pray let me see the issue.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: I therefore seeke to keepe it,— now burst out
Thou filthy streame of trouble, spite and doubt.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Oh an extent, a Proclamation, a Summons, a Recognisance, a Tachment. and Iniunction, a Writ, a Seysure, a Writ of praeisement, an Absolution, a Quietus est.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You'r quieter I hope by so much Dreggs.
Beholde my Lord:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: This, why it out frownes Inke:

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: Tis the diseases Nature, the Fiends drinke.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Oh sicke, sick, Signior Ply-fee, sicke: lend me thy Nightcap, oh!

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The Balsum of a temperate braine,
I poure into this thirstie veine,
And with this blessed oyle of quiet,
Which is so cheape, that few men buy it,
Thy stormie Temples I allay,
Thou shalt giue vp the Diuell and pray,
Forsake his works, they're foule and black,
And keepe thee bare in pursse and backe.
No more shalt thou in paper quarrell,
To dresse vp Apes in good apparell.
He throwes his stocke, and all his flocke,
Into a swallowing gulfe,
That sendes his Goose vnto his Foxe,
His Lambe vnto his Wolfe.
Keepe thy encrease,
And liue at peace,
For war's not equall to this battaile,
That eates but men this men and cattaile,
Therefore no more this combate choose:
Where he that wins, do's alwayes loose,
And those that gaine all, with this cursse receiue it,
From fooles they get it, to their sonnes they leaue it.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Haile sacred patience, I begin to feele
sp.p: I haue a Conscience now, Truth in my words, Compassion in my hart, & aboue al, in my blood peaces musick,
sp.l: Vse me how you can,
You shall find me an honest-quiet man.
Oh, pardon, that I dare behold that face,
"Now I'ue least law, I hope haue most grace,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: We both admire the work-man and his peece:
Thus when all hearts are tunde to Honors strings,
There is no musicke to the Quire of Kings.

div.head: Prologus
div.l: THe markes and notions extant in each spirit,
Seald by th'industrious hand of art & merit,
Me thinkes appeare transparant (as the minde
By fence were bounded and might seeme confind
In th' externall eye) nor shall our tragicke muse,
(If strong hope faile not) need a coynd excuse
But to those marginall noates of yours do bring
(In following nombers from the learned spring)
Matter instructiue to inrich their parts
Where knowledge raignes crownd with it own desarts,
Let such with serious and impartiall hearing
Sound sence, quicke sight and iudgement neuer erring:
Suruay and censure the mineruall frame
Of his elaborate worke: and if his name
Merrit regard, and you vouchsafe to grace him
With eminent loue, or mongst those lawreats place him,
That with the magicke of sweet poesie,
Transfer Pernassus into Brittany,
He shall digest the Chaos of his braine,
To tunefull order and acquire a straine,
Neere to the musicke of the heauenly spheres,
To fit Times guard and rauish choysest eares.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: FAme and Opinion like the two wingd cap
On Hermes head, do lift all Poets vp:
Some, though deseruing, yet aboue the Sphere
Of true impartiall censure, whose tun'd eare
Listens to all and can with iudgement say,
Others sing well, though Thracian Orpheus play.
Our Muse affects no excellence: if Fame tell
And through her shrill trompe at the Muses well
(Where the thrice trebled bench of learning sits
In strict examination of others wits)
Sound ours, thogh humbly straines, whose infant growth
Nor dares, nor will, with times hugd darlings quarrell,
Nor stand the lightning with the sacred Lawrell)
We rest content: yet thus farre may conceipt
Carry each labouring Artist, where the weight
Of his oyld taske is ouer, that his tongue
May like a father of his tender young
Speak natures language and not be withstood,
When with our Muse he saith, that This is good.

div.p: This Epilogue should haue bene printed at the end of the booke, but there was no spare place for it.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
